open_questions.title: DevOps, and why is it important
open_questions.description: What is DevOps, and why is it important?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is DevOps, and why is it important?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: DevOps is a set of practices that aim to automate and integrate the processes of software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops). It's important because it improves collaboration, accelerates software delivery, increases reliability, and enhances overall efficiency in the software development lifecycle.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The CI/CD pipeline.
open_questions.description: Explain the CI/CD pipeline.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the CI/CD pipeline.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The CI/CD pipeline is a set of automated processes that facilitate Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Deployment (CD) of software. It includes stages like code compilation, testing, and deployment to ensure that changes are tested thoroughly and deployed to production automatically if they pass all tests.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Some popular CI/CD tools, and can
open_questions.description: What are some popular CI/CD tools, and can you explain their roles?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are some popular CI/CD tools, and can you explain their roles?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Some popular CI/CD tools include Jenkins, Travis CI, CircleCI, and GitLab CI/CD. These tools automate the building, testing, and deployment of code. For example, Jenkins is known for its flexibility and extensibility, allowing developers to create custom pipelines, while GitLab CI/CD integrates seamlessly with GitLab for an all-in-one solution.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Infrastructure as Code is the practice of managing and provisioning infrastructure using code. It benefits DevOps by enabling the automation of infrastructure deployment, improving consistency, and making it easier to version, test, and maintain infrastructure configurations.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: DevOps Principles include collaboration, automation, continuous integration, continuous delivery, monitoring, and feedback. They guide DevOps teams by emphasizing a culture of collaboration, automation of repetitive tasks, integration of development and operations, continuous delivery of value to users, and continuous improvement through feedback loops.

open_questions.title: You handle security in a DevOps

Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Security is a critical concern in DevOps. I ensure security by implementing security scans and tests in the CI/CD pipeline, using tools like static code analysis, vulnerability scanning, and penetration testing. Additionally, I follow best practices like least privilege access, regular patching, and compliance checks.

referenceAnswers.text: Example answer: I once encountered a production issue where an application was experiencing high CPU utilization. I started by gathering data from monitoring tools and logs to identify the root cause. I then isolated the problematic code, optimized it, and applied a fix. After testing in a staging environment, I deployed the solution to production, and monitoring confirmed that the issue was resolved.

open_questions.title: Can you explain Blue-Green deployments and
open_questions.description: Can you explain Blue-Green deployments and how they work?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Can you explain Blue-Green deployments and how they work?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Blue-Green deployments involve running two identical environments (blue and green) concurrently. You deploy new code to the green environment while the blue environment continues to serve production traffic. Once testing is successful, you switch traffic from blue to green, making green the new production environment. This allows for quick rollbacks if issues arise.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of "Blue-Green" and "Canary"
open_questions.description: Describe the concept of "Blue-Green" and "Canary" deployments. When would you use each one?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Describe the concept of "Blue-Green" and "Canary" deployments. When would you use each one?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Blue-Green deployments involve switching traffic between two identical environments. Canary deployments release a new version to a small subset of users. Blue-Green is used for minimizing downtime and enabling quick rollbacks, while Canary is useful for gradual testing and monitoring of new features or changes.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between a container and
open_questions.description: What is the difference between a container and a virtual machine, and when would you choose one over the other?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between a container and a virtual machine, and when would you choose one over the other?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Containers are lightweight, share the host OS kernel, and are faster to start compared to virtual machines (VMs). VMs provide full isolation with their own OS. I'd choose containers for microservices and applications with consistent environments, and VMs for legacy applications or when strong isolation is required.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of "Immutable Infrastructure".
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of "Immutable Infrastructure".?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of "Immutable Infrastructure".?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Immutable Infrastructure means that once an infrastructure component is deployed, it is never modified; instead, a new one is created to replace it. This ensures consistency, reduces configuration drift, and simplifies rollback and scaling.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of "Infrastructure as Code"
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of "Infrastructure as Code" (IaC) drift and how to prevent it.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of "Infrastructure as Code" (IaC) drift and how to prevent it.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Example answer: IaC drift occurs when the actual infrastructure configuration deviates from what's defined in the code. To prevent it, I regularly apply changes only through code updates, use tools to detect drift (like AWS Config), and enforce strict change control processes.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: this keyword
open_questions.description: Explain the difference between a stateless and stateful application. How does this impact the design of a DevOps pipeline?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the difference between a stateless and stateful application. How does this impact the design of a DevOps pipeline?" Requirements: - `this` depends on call-site (how the function is invoked) - Method call vs plain function call - Arrow functions capture lexical `this` - `bind`/`call`/`apply` can set `this` Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: this depends on call-site (how the function is invoked); Method call vs plain function call; Arrow functions capture lexical this; bind/call/apply can set this. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Stateless applications do not store user session data, while stateful applications maintain session data between requests. This impacts the design of a DevOps pipeline as stateful applications may require more complex deployment strategies, like rolling updates or database migrations, compared to stateless apps.

Method call vs plain function call
Arrow functions capture lexical `this`
`bind`/`call`/`apply` can set `this`

open_questions.title: The concept of "Chaos Engineering" in
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of "Chaos Engineering" in DevOps, and why is it valuable?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of "Chaos Engineering" in DevOps, and why is it valuable?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Chaos Engineering is the practice of intentionally introducing controlled failures or chaos into a system to uncover vulnerabilities and weaknesses. It's valuable in DevOps because it helps identify and address issues proactively, improve system resilience, and build confidence in the system's behavior under adverse conditions.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: "GitOps," and how does it differ
open_questions.description: What is "GitOps," and how does it differ from traditional DevOps practices?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is "GitOps," and how does it differ from traditional DevOps practices?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: GitOps is a DevOps methodology that uses Git as the single source of truth for both infrastructure and application code. It emphasizes declarative definitions stored in Git repositories to drive automation. GitOps differs from traditional DevOps practices as it simplifies and centralizes the management of infrastructure and configurations.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Automated testing is critical in DevOps for ensuring code quality and reliability. Automated tests help catch defects early, reduce manual intervention, and facilitate faster and more reliable deployments.

open_questions.title: A Docker image and how is

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Docker image is a lightweight, stand-alone, executable package that contains everything needed to run a piece of software, including the code, runtime, libraries, and system tools. A Docker container is a running instance of a Docker image. Containers are isolated from each other and the host system.

Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Discuss the concept of Feature Flags

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Feature Flags are a development technique that allows developers to enable or disable specific features in an application without deploying new code. They can be used in a DevOps pipeline to manage feature releases by gradually rolling out features to specific user groups, conducting A/B testing, and easily rolling back changes if issues arise.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Example answer: I ensure that my CI/CD pipeline supports rollbacks by having a process to revert to the previous known good state. This might involve using blue-green deployments, canary releases, or keeping backup versions of the infrastructure. Automated testing and monitoring help detect issues early and trigger rollbacks when necessary.

open_questions.title: Discuss the Cattle vs. Pets analogy
open_questions.description: Discuss the Cattle vs. Pets analogy in the context of server management. How does it relate to DevOps practices?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Discuss the Cattle vs. Pets analogy in the context of server management. How does it relate to DevOps practices?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The Cattle vs. Pets analogy categorizes servers as either replaceable and disposable like cattle or unique and valuable like pets. DevOps practices align with treating servers like cattle, emphasizing automation, scalability, and easy replacement, rather than investing significant effort in managing individual servers.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: The Four Key Metrics framework includes Lead Time, Deployment Frequency, Change Failure Rate, and Mean Time to Recovery (MTTR). They provide insights into areas for improvement and help teams optimize their workflows.

open_questions.title: The Principle of Least Privilege and
open_questions.description: Explain the Principle of Least Privilege and how it applies to DevOps security practices.?

referenceAnswers.text: The Principle of Least Privilege dictates that individuals or systems should have the minimum level of access or permissions necessary to perform their tasks. In DevOps, it means granting only the necessary permissions to users, applications, and services to minimize security risks, limit potential damage, and reduce attack surfaces.

referenceAnswers.text: The First Way (Flow): Focuses on optimizing the flow of work from development to production to deliver value quickly. The Second Way (Feedback): Emphasizes obtaining feedback quickly, enabling fast detection and correction of issues. The Third Way (Continuous Learning and Experimentation): Encourages a culture of learning from failures and continually experimenting to improve processes and outcomes.

open_questions.title: The key differences between Git and
open_questions.description: What are the key differences between Git and SVN (Subversion), and why is Git preferred in DevOps?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the key differences between Git and SVN (Subversion), and why is Git preferred in DevOps?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Git is distributed, whereas SVN is centralized. Git is preferred in DevOps due to its ability to work offline, its faster branching and merging capabilities, and its support for distributed development, making it easier to collaborate and manage code changes in a dynamic environment.

Mention a common pitfall or best practice
